journal-meta.journal-title: Proceedings of the Institution of Mechanical Engineers, Part G: Journal of Aerospace Engineering

title-group.article-title: Optimal linear attitude estimator and its recursive algorithm via geometric analysis

article-meta.aff: Institute of Aerospace Science and Technology, Shanghai Jiaotong University, People's Republic of China

author-notes.corresp: Deren Gong, Institute of Aerospace Science and Technology, Shanghai Jiaotong University, Rm. 2410, Aerospace Building, No. 800, Dongchuan Road, Shanghai 200240, People's Republic of China. Email: drgong@sjtu.edu.cn

abstract.p: A new optimal linear attitude estimator is proposed for single-point attitude estimation using geometric approach, and a recursive optimal linear attitude estimator is developed through filtering noisy measurements. Dot and cross products are taken in order to eliminate the unknown parameters of relationships between measurements and Gibbs vector. The optimality criterion, which does not coincide with Wahba’s constrained criterion, yields linear attitude estimate. A prior rotation is adopted to avoid singularity which occurs when the principal angle is close to π. The recursive algorithm is achieved for the purpose of improving attitude accuracy using all past measurements. For long-term space missions, memory fading concept is introduced into recursive optimal linear attitude estimator. The optimal relative weighting is obtained through minimizing error propagation, and an efficient modification is proposed to significantly reduce the sudden increase of attitude error of recursive optimal linear attitude estimator in special cases. Numerical simulations show that the estimate of optimal linear attitude estimator is almost identical with that of the famous QUaternion ESTimator, and the accuracy provided by recursive optimal linear attitude estimator is over an order magnitude higher than that of optimal linear attitude estimator or QUaternion ESTimator in most cases.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: In 1965, Wahba1 formulated the attitude determination problem using vector observations as a least-squares estimation problem which seeks the proper orthogonal matrix (attitude matrix, direction-cosine matrix) A that minimizes the cost function (1)J(A)=12∑i=1nξi||bi-Ari||2 where the sequence bi, 1mui=1,2,…,n of unit vectors are the results of measurements performed in vehicle Cartesian coordinates of the directions to known objects. The sequence ri, 1mui=1,2,…,n of unit vectors are the corresponding unit vectors resolved in a reference Cartesian coordinate system and ξi, 1mui=1,2,…,n, a set of positive weights such that ∑i=1nξi=1.

The Wahba problem has been solved a number of ways which generally fall into two categories: single-point (SP) algorithms and recursive algorithms. The method of SP algorithms includes a set, and only this set, of simultaneous measurements at time k used to estimate the quaternion. Cheng and Shuster2 analyzed numbers of SP algorithms with two classes: First, obtain the attitude profile matrix B or the Davenport matrix K using algorithms of Numerical Linear Algebra.3,4 Such examples can be found in Farrell and Stuelpnagel5 using a polar-decomposition method; matrix square-root algorithms in Wessner6 and Brock7 the famous Davenport q-method in and Shuster8 and Shuster and Oh9 and SVD algorithm.10 The other solution methods are a kind of iterative solutions which seek λmax, the maximum characteristic value of the Davenport matrix K by some method specially designed to solve the Wahba problem. Examples of those methods can be referred to Shuster’s well-known QUaternion ESTimator (QUEST),8,9 FOAM11 proposed by Markley and Mortari’s3 ESOQ and ESOQ2 algorithms.12–14 Cheng and Shuster2 also provided a detailed analysis of those algorithms mentioned above with respect to computational efficiency. Of the most interesting ones is the Mortari’s optimal linear attitude estimator (OLAE) using Rodrigues (or Gibbs) vector.15,16 Mortari’s optimality criterion is based on Cayler transformation between the attitude matrix and Rodrigues vector. Motivated by Mortari’s work, Gong et al.17 provided three linear attitude estimators via geometric analysis of rigid rotation. In summary, any SP attitude determination estimator is a batch estimator where the information contained in past measurements is lost.

The recursive forms of some estimators are proposed since they use the past data without requiring their storage, and allow real-time processing of new incoming observations. Shuster18 proposed an implementation of the Wahba problem for dynamic systems as a sequential filter and smoother, known as Filter QUEST and Smoother QUEST. Bar-Itzhack19 provided a recursive modification of QUEST Algorithm for Sequential Attitude Determination, which is called REQUEST. The most recent research results in this field include Optimal-REQUEST,20 which is an optimal recursive time-varying estimator of the quaternion, and Shuster21 analyzed the relationship between Filter QUEST and REQUEST in detail. Daniel22 proposed a quaternion estimation using Kalman filtering of the vectorized K matrix.

This article proposes a new OLAE for solving the SP attitude determination problem, and a recursive OLAE (REOLAE) for the purpose of improving attitude accuracy using all past measurements. OLAE is achieved with the linear relationships between measurements and Gibbs vector. New optimality criterion does not coincide with Wahba’s constrained criterion. The final results of linear attitude estimators are represented by modified Rodrigues parameters (MRPs). Memory fading concept is introduced into REOLAE to adaptively reduce attitude error.

The structure of this article is as follows: First, geometric analysis of rotation is presented for obtaining components of the Gibbs vector projected in the incidental right-hand orthogonal coordinate system, OLAE is proposed and singularity avoidance obtained by a prior rotation. Next, REOLAE is achieved including time-invariant and time-varying algorithms. The error propagation is analyzed and the memory fading factor optimized. Finally, numerical simulations are conducted to quantify and compare the accuracy of the proposed estimators with QUEST algorithm.

sec.title: Geometric analysis of rotation
sec.p: Based on Euler’s theorem, which states that any rotation of a body (or coordinate system) with respect to another may be described by a single rotation through some angle about a single fixed axis, the direction cosine matrix A can be represented as (2)A(a,θ)=cosθI+(1-cosθ)aaT-sinθa× where I denotes the 3×3 identity matrix, a the axis of rotation, θ the angle of rotation, and a× a skew-symmetric matrix generated by a, having the following structure (3)a×=g[0-a3a2a30-a1-a2a10g]

According to the concept of attitude kinematics, the relationship between the body and reference vectors can be expressed as (4)bi=A(a,θ)ri Premultiplying equation (4) by aT yields the result (5)aTbi=aTA(a,θ)ri=aTri

This means that the angle between bi and a is equivalent to that between ri and a. Moreover, using equation (2), the dot product of ri and bi can be given by (6)riTbi=riTA(a,θ)ri=cosθ+(1-cosθ)(aTri)2 Substituting equation (5) into equation (6), it is obtained that (7)cosθ=riTbi-(aTri)21-(aTri)2=[bi-(aTbi)a]T[ri-(aTri)a]||bi-(aTbi)a||·||ri-(aTri)a||

This indicates that θ is just the angle between [bi-(aTbi)a] and [ri-(aTri)a]. Using equations (5) and (7), the implication is that ri can be obtained by rotating the vector bi through rotation angle θ about the axis a in a constant reference coordinate system, as illustrated in Figure 1. Figure 1.
Geometric relationship of rotation.

For each pair of measured values {ri,1mubi}, we define a corresponding right-hand orthogonal coordinate system as follows (8)xi=(ri+bi)/2yi=(ri-bi)/2zi=xi×yi The vectors defined in equation (8) may not be unit vectors, and their magnitudes are given by (9)xi=g|xig|yi=g|yig|zi=g|zig|

According to equation (5), we have aTyi=0, i.e. the axis of rotation a has non-zero components only along xi and zi coordinates. Thus, a can be written in the following form (10)a=cosαixixi+sinαizizi where αi denotes the angle between xi and a.
Notice that the relationship among angles αi, βi, and θ, as shown in Figure 1, can be summarized as (11)sinαitanθ2=tanβi=yixi where βi denotes the angle between xi and bi.

The Gibbs vector, which is widely used in attitude representation, is defined as (12)g=tanθ2a Substituting equations (10) and (11) into equation (12) yields (13)g=cotαiyixi2xi+yixizizi This means that g has known components projected in yi and zi coordinates. This property is very important and will be used in the following linear attitude estimator.

sec.title: Optimal linear attitude estimate algorithm
sec.p: The OLAE can be obtained using dot and cross products to eliminate the unknown angle αi from equation (13). Premultiplying equation (13) by yiT, xiziT, and xi×/xi, respectively, the following can be developed (14)g.yiTg=0xiziTg-yizi=0xi×g+yi=0g} Equation (14) cannot be satisfied by all the n measurements, due to the presence of sensor noise. In this article, it is supposed that the observed body vectors are given by (15)b~i=bi+vi where vi denotes the error of observations. Thus, the error vector for a given Gibbs vector g can be chosen as (16)e~i=g[y~iTgx~iz~iTg-y~iz~ix~i×g+y~ig] where (17)x~i=(ri+b~i)/2 x~i=g|x~ig|y~i=(ri-b~i)/2 y~i=g|y~ig|z~i=x~i×y~i z~i=g|z~ig| This allows us to introduce a new optimality criterion for vehicle attitude. The optimal attitude estimate is defined as finding a Gibbs vector g, which minimizes the following quadratic cost function (18)J=12∑i=1nξig |e~ig |2 where ξi, i=1,2,…,n denote a set of relative positive weights. Substituting equations (16) and (17) into equation (18), the optimality criterion expression can be obtained in terms of attitude and observation vectors (19)J=12∑i=1nξi[gT(y~iy~iT+x~i2z~iz~iT-x~i×x~i×)g +2gT(x~i×y~i-2x~iy~iz~iz~i)+y~i2z~i2+y~i2]=116∑i=1nξig{gTg([4(1-riTb~i)I-4(ri×b~i×+b~i×ri×) -(1+riTb~i)b~i×ririTb~i×]g)gg(-2g[5-(riTb~i)2g]gTb~i×ri+(1-riTb~i)g[5-(riTb~i)2g]g}g) Define (20)M~=∑i=1nξi[4(1-riTb~i)I-4(ri×b~i×+b~i×ri×) -(1+riTb~i)b~i×ririTb~i×]υ~=∑i=1nξi[5-(riTb~i)2]b~i×rid~=∑i=1nξi(1-riTb~i)g[5-(riTb~i)2g] Thus, the optimality criterion can be rewritten as (21)J=116(gTM~g-2gTυ~+d~) Since this is an unconstrained minimization, stationarity conditions to minimize equation (21) yield (22)∂J∂g=18(M~g-υ~)=0

Notice that M~, which is just the second derivative of the cost function J with respect to g, is a real symmetric positive definite matrix for n⩾2. Therefore, the global minimum of J can be achieved by (23)M~·g∧=υ~ where g∧ denotes the optimal Gibbs vector as a result of OLAE. According to the relationship between the Gibbs and the MRP vectors, the final results of linear attitude estimators are represented by MRP, i.e. (24)σ∧=g∧1+1+g∧Tg∧

sec.title: Singularity avoidance
sec.p: Due to the use of Gibbs vector, singularity occurs when the principal angle is close to π. In this article, we adopt the method of one prior rotation of reference directions. When the principal angle is π, bi=A(a,π)ri=2aaTri-ri, and the error-free M matrix satisfies (25)Ma=∑i=1nξi[4(1-riTbi)a-4(ri×bi×+bi×ri×)a -(1+riTbi)bi×ririTbi×a]=8∑i=1nξig[(1-(aTri)2)a-(aTri)a×ri×a+ri×ri×ag]=0 This indicates that M is a singular matrix, and miTa=0, i=1,2,3, where mi is the ith column vector of MT. Introduce a prior rotation represented by a Gibbs vector (26)g=a~=m~1×m~2|m~1×m~2| whose associated MRP vector is σ=a~1+2, where m~1 and m~2 denote the first and second column vectors of noisy matrix M~T. And import a new Gibbs vector g∧* which satisfies (27)g∧*=g⊗g∧=(I-g×)g∧+g1-gTg∧g∧=g-1⊗g∧*=(I+g×)g∧*-g1+gTg∧* Thus, g∧* can be calculated from following equations (28)M~·g∧=M~·(I+g×)g∧*-g1+gTg∧*=υ~ (29)g∧*=g[M~(I+g×)-υ~gTg]-1(υ~+M~g) and σ∧* is then obtained (30)σ∧*=g∧*1+1+g∧*Tg∧*
Consequently, the optimal MRP vector σ∧ without singularity can be achieved (31)σ∧=σ-1⊗σ∧*=σ∧*(1-σTσ)-σ(1-σ∧*Tσ∧*)+2σ×σ∧*1+2σTσ*+σTσσ∧*Tσ∧*

sec.title: Recursive time-invariant algorithm
sec.p: Assume that the body directions keep still with respect to the reference coordinate system. At time tk, mk-1 old measurements have been processed at the last sample time, and nk new measurements will be performed. Let ξk,i, rk,i, and b~k,i denote the ith weight, reference vector, and observed vector at time tk, respectively, and M~k and υ~k represent the matrix and vector used to calculate the estimated Gibbs vector g∧k=M~k-1υ~k.

According to equation (20), M~k and υ~k can be given by (32)g{M~k=1μk∑j=1k∑i=1njξj,ig[4(1-rj,iTb~j,i)I-4(rj,i×b~j,i×+b~j,i×rk,i×) -(1+rj,iTb~j,i)b~j,i×rj,irj,iTb~j,i×g]υ~k=1μk∑j=1k∑i=1njξj,i[5-(rj,iTb~j,i)2]b~j,i×rj,ig. where μk=∑j=1k∑i=1njξj,i denotes the amounts of weights of all past and new measurements at time tk. Inspecting the form of equation (32), the recursive expressions of M~k, υ~k, and d~k can be obtained (33)g{M~k=μk-1μkM~k-1+δukμkδM~kυ~k=μk-1μkυ~k-1+δukμkδυ~kg. where δM~k and δυ~k are the new information added into the recursive process equation (33), having the following form (34)g{δM~k=1δμk∑i=1nkξk,ig[4(1-rk,iTb~k,i)I-4(rk,i×b~k,i×+b~k,i×rk,i×) -(1+rk,iTb~k,i)b~k,i×rk,irk,iTb~k,i×g]δυ~k=1δμk∑i=1nkξk,i[5-(rk,iTb~k,i)2]b~k,i×rk,ig. and μk=uk-1+δuk, δuk=∑i=1nkξk,i.

sec.title: Recursive time-varying algorithm
sec.p: Assume that the body directions are rotating with respect to the reference frame during the interval [tk-1,tk], and the angular velocity is a constant vector ωk-1. Let Δtk-1=tk-tk-1; the rotation caused by the angular velocity can be parameterized by a Gibbs vector gk-1 which is given by (35)gk-1=ωk-1ωk-1tanωk-1Δtk-12 where ωk-1=||ωk-1|| denotes the magnitude of angular velocity. Define the predicted Gibbs vector, denoted by g∧k/k-1, to represent the attitude at time tk based on the g∧k-1 and ωk-1. According to the geometric relationship of body rotation, we have (36)g∧k/k-1=gk-1⊗g∧k-1=(I-gk-1×)g∧k-1+gk-11-gk-1Tg∧k-1g∧k-1=gk-1-1⊗g∧k/k-1=(I+gk-1×)g∧k/k-1-gk-11+gk-1Tg∧k/k-1

If g∧k-1 is the optimal estimated Gibbs vector by minimizing the following cost function (37)Jk-1=116(gk-1TM~k-1gk-1-2gk-1Tυ~k-1+d~k-1) The problem naturally occurs: how to find the optimal g∧k/k-1 only using the all past measurements. Substituting equation (36) into equation (37), the cost function becomes (38)Jk/k-1=116g{g[(I+gk-1×)g∧k/k-1-gk-11+gk-1Tg∧k/k-1g]T ×M~k-1g[(I+gk-1×)g∧k/k-1-gk-11+gk-1Tg∧k/k-1g]-2g[(I+gk-1×)g∧k/k-1-gk-11+gk-1Tg∧k/k-1g]Tυ~k-1+d~k-1g} where the symbol Jk/k-1 is used instead of Jk-1. The first-order optimality conditions of equation (38) is given by (39)∂Jk/k-1∂g∧k/k-1=18g[∂g∧k-1∂g∧k/k-1g]Tg{M~k-1g[(I+gk-1×)g∧k/k-1-gk-11+gk-1Tg∧k/k-1g]-υ~k-1g} where (40)g[∂g∧k-1∂g∧k/k-1g]=(I+gk-1×)(I-gk-1×g∧k/k-1×)+gk-1gk-1T(1+gk-1Tg∧k/k-1)2

Equation (40) shows that [∂g∧k-1∂g∧k/k-1] is an invertible matrix. Thus, the optimal g∧k/k-1 satisfies the following equations (41)M~k-1g[(I+gk-1×)g∧k/k-1-gk-11+gk-1Tg∧k/k-1g]-υ~k-1=0 Expanding equation (41) yields (42)g[M~k-1(I+gk-1×)-υ~k-1gk-1Tg]g∧k/k-1=υ~k-1+M~k-1gk-1 Let (43)g{M~k/k-1=M~k-1(I+gk-1×)-υ~k-1gk-1Tυ~k/k-1=υ~k-1+M~k-1gk-1g.
Consequently, g∧k/k-1=M~k/k-1-1υ~k/k-1 are obtained.

Now we have established the process of prediction that M~k/k-1 and υ~k/k-1 are the proper variables for finding the optimal attitude estimated at time tk based on all past measurements. According to equation (33), the recursive time-varying algorithm can be developed as follows (44)g{M~k=μk-1μkM~k/k-1+δukμkδM~kυ~k=μk-1μkυ~k/k-1+δukμkδυ~kg.

sec.title: Error propagation
sec.p: In this section, we analyze the error propagation using a cost function J¯ defined as follows (45)J¯=tr(E[ΔMΔMT+ΔυΔυT]) where ΔM and Δυ denote the error of M matrix and υ vector in the process of attitude determination, respectively. Assume that noises generated by distinct sensors are independent, and noises produced by the same sensor at different sampling time are also uncorrelated.

According to equation (34), the errors of δMk and δυk can be given by (46)g{ΔδMk=-1δμk∑i=1nkξk,ig[(rk,iTvk,i)Bk,i-Ck,iTvk,i×+vk,i×Ck,ig]Δδυk=-1δμk∑i=1nkξk,iDk,ivk,ig. where (47)Bk,i=4I+bk,i×rk,irk,iTbk,i×Ck,i=4rk,i×+(1+rk,iTbk,i)rk,irk,iTbk,i×Dk,i=[5-(rk,iTbk,i)2]rk,i×+2(rk,iTbk,i)bk,i×rk,irk,iT Thus, we have (48)δJ¯k=tr(E[ΔδMkΔδMkT+ΔδυkΔδυkT])=1δμk2trg{∑i=1nkξk,i2g[rk,iT·E(vk,ivk,iT)·rk,iBk,iBk,i +Dk,i·E(vk,ivk,iT)·Dk,iT +Bk,i·E(rk,iTvk,ivk,i×)·Ck,i +E(rk,iTvk,ivk,i×)·Ck,iBk,i -Bk,iCk,iT·E(rk,iTvk,ivk,i×) -Ck,iT·E(rk,iTvk,ivk,i×)·Bk,i Ck,iT·E(vk,i×Ck,iTvk,i×) +E(vk,i×Ck,ivk,i×)·Ck,i -Ck,iT·E(vk,i×vk,i×)·Ck,i -E(vk,i×Ck,iCk,iTvk,i×)g]g} Assume that the errors of observation are Gaussian white noises, i.e. (49)E[vk,i]=0,E[vk,ivl,jT]=ςk,iI3δk,lδi,j where ςk,i is the variance of the component of vk,i and δk,l the Kronecker delta function. Using (50)E(rk,iTvk,ivk,i×)=ςk,irk,i×,E(vk,i×Ck,ivk,i×)=-4rk,i×-rk,i×(bk,i×rk,i)×E(vk,i×vk,i×)=-2ςk,iI,E(vk,i×Ck,iTvk,i×)=-4rk,i×+(bk,i×rk,i)×rk,i×E(vk,i×Ck,iCk,iTvk,i×)=g[3(1+rk,iTbk,i)2(rk,iTbk,i×bk,i×rk,i)+16g] ×rk,i×rk,i×+32I

Equation (48) becomes (51)δJ¯k=ςk,iδμk2∑i=1nkξk,i2trg[rk,iTrk,iBk,iBk,i+Dk,iDk,iT +Bk,irk,i×Ck,i +rk,i×Ck,iBk,i-Bk,iCk,iTrk,i× -Ck,iTrk,i×Bk,i-4Ck,iTrk,i× -4rk,i×Ck,i+Ck,iT(bk,i×rk,i)×rk,i× -rk,i×(bk,i×rk,i)×Ck,i+2Ck,iTCk,i -3(1+rk,iTbk,i)2(rk,iTbk,i×bk,i×rk,i) rk,i×rk,i×-16rk,i×rk,i×-32Ig] In a practical process, a common sensor that measures the angular rate is a rate-integrating gyro. The error of angular velocity is modeled as a zero-mean white-noise vector; that is (52)E[εk]=0,E[εkεjT]=ηkI3δk,j where ηk is the variance of the component of εk. Then, the error of gk-1 is approximated to (53)Δgk-1=gk-1-gk-1o≈1ωk-13g[ωk-1Δtk-12sec2ωk-1Δtk-12ggωk-1ωk-1T-tanωk-1Δtk-12ωk-1×ωk-1×g]εk-1 where gk-1o is the true attitude rotation caused by angular velocity. It is supposed that the sampling rate is fast enough such that ωk-1Δtk-1 <<1, then (54)gk-1≈Δtk-12ωk-1,Δgk-1≈Δtk-12εk-1 and (55)Eg[Δgk-1Δgk-1Tg]≈Δtk-124εk-1εk-1T=ηk-1Δtk-124I3

According to equation (43), we have (56)g{ΔMk/k-1=ΔMk-1(I+gk-1×)-Δυk-1gk-1T+Mk-1Δgk-1×-υk-1Δgk-1TΔυk/k-1=Δυk-1+ΔMk-1gk-1+Mk-1Δgk-1g. where ΔMk-1=ΔM~k-1-Mk-1 and Δυk-1=υ~k-1-υk-1 denote the error of M matrix and υ vector at time tk-1, Mk-1, and υk-1 denote the true values. Equation (56) yields that (57)J¯k/k-1=tr(E[ΔMk/k-1ΔMk/k-1TΔυk/k-1Δυk/k-1T])=trg{Eg[g[ΔMk-1(I+gk-1×)-Δυk-1gk-1Tg]g[ΔMk-1(I+gk-1×)-Δυk-1gk-1Tg]T+g[Δυk-1+ΔMk-1gk-1g]g[Δυk-1+ΔMk-1gk-1g]Tg]+Eg(Δgk-1TΔgk-1g)υk-1υk-1T+2Mk-1Eg(Δgk-1Δgk-1Tg)Mk-1Tg}=g{(1+gk-1Tgk-1)·tr(E[ΔMk-1ΔMk-1T+Δυk-1Δυk-1T])+E[Δgk-1TΔgk-1]·tr(Mk-1Mk-1T+υk-1υk-1T)g} Substituting equation (55) into equation (57), the predicated J¯k/k-1 based on old measurements can be obtained (58)J¯k/k-1=g(1+ωk-12Δtk-124g)J¯k-1+3ηk-1Δtk-124 trg(Mk-1Mk-1T+vk-1vk-1Tg) It indicates that the error is approximately a quadratic equation with respect to interval, and high sampling rate could restrain the growth of the estimate error of REOLAE.

According to the recursive process of M~ matrix and υ~ vector in equation (44), the cost function J¯k can be given by (59)J¯k=tr(E[ΔMkΔMkT+ΔυkΔυkT])=trg{Eg[g(μk-1μkΔMk/k-1+δukμkΔδMkg)g(μk-1μkΔMk/k-1+δukμkΔδMkg)T+g(μk-1μkΔυk/k-1+δukμkΔδυkg)g(μk-1μkΔυk/k-1+δukμkΔδυkg)Tg]g}=μk-12μk2J¯k/k-1+δμk2μk2δJ¯k

sec.title: Optimal REOLAE
sec.p: As mentioned by Bar-Itzhack, space missions are of long duration. Thus, the initial measurements are propagated through the repeated use of equation (44) to the current time. As time goes, it in turn reduces the accuracy of attitude estimate. In order to decrease the influence of old measurements, the fading memory concept is adopted. In the process of updating M~ and υ~, we use the following algorithm instead of equation (44) (60)g{M~k=(1-ρk)μk-1μkM~k/k-1+ρkδukμkδM~kυ~k=(1-ρk)μk-1μkυ~k/k-1+ρkδukμkδυ~kg. where 0⩽ρk⩽1, the scalars μk are recursively computed by (61)μk=(1-ρk)μk-1+ρkδuk

Notice that ρk denotes the relative weight between past and present measurements. If ρk=0, only old measurements are used to calculate the current attitude. If ρk=1, all past measurements are discarded, and REOLAE becomes OLAE. If ρk=0.5, the past and present measurements have equivalent weights. Thus, the optimal REOLAE is to design an updating law of ρk by minimizing a certain optimality criterion.

In the previous section, the error propagation was analyzed. Here, we employ the cost function J¯ as the optimality criterion to obtain the optimal ρk*. Then, the minimization problem with respect to ρk is given by (62)minJ¯ks.t.J¯k=(1-ρk)2μk-12μk2J¯k/k-1+ρk2δμk2μk2δJ¯k,ρk∈[0,1] where J¯k/k-1 and δJ¯k can be calculated using equations (48) and (58). The first-order necessary condition for an extremum of J¯ yields (63)dJ¯kdρk=2g[(ρk-1)μk-12μk2J¯k/k-1+ρkδμk2μk2δJ¯kg]=0 resulting in the following condition for ρk* to yield a stationary point for J¯k(64)ρk*=μk-12J¯k/k-1μk-12J¯k/k-1+δμk2δJ¯k It can be verified that J¯k reaches its minimum at ρk*, using the sufficiency condition.

sec.title: Numerical simulations
sec.p: The accuracy of the proposed OLAE and REOLAE compared with QUEST is quantified here with an extensive Monte Carlo numerical analysis. Assume that the body coordinate system is fixed or rotating with a constant angular velocity with respect to the reference coordinate system. The observation noises are Gaussian white noises with zero mean and SD 10-3 rad. The gyro noises are also Gaussian white noises with a SD of 0.2°/h in each axis. The sample rate is 10 Hz, both in vector observations and gyro measurements. The observed directions in body coordinate system are [1,0,0]T, [0,1,0]T, and [0,0,1]T.

In order to highlight the accuracy provided by an attitude estimator, the attitude error vector for the Gibbs parameters is defined as follows (65)δθ=2g∧εg-1=2g∧-g+g∧×g1+g∧Tg And the scale attitude error is given by (66)δθ=δθTδθ

In the case where the body is fixed with respect to the reference coordinate system, the results of three estimators, i.e. QUEST, OLAE, and REOLAE, are plotted in Figure 2. The simulation time is 1000 s, and the measurement data and attitudes are 10,000 times, randomly produced using sensor noises. It is shown that
OLAE provides attitude accuracy which is almost identical with that of QUEST.
The attitude error REOLAE is far lower than that of OLAE or QUEST. In terms of the mean value of scale attitude error, δθQUEST≈δθOLAE≈16.232δθREOLAE.
The optimal relative weighting ρk* decreases with time going, and yields high precision of REOLAE.
Figure 2.
Attitude accuracy plots (fixed).

In this case, the body is rotating with an angular velocity ω=[0.01,-0.02,0.03]T. The results of these tests are plotted in Figure 3. Notice that REOLAE provides a better estimated attitude than OLAE and QUEST in most cases, while the attitude error may suddenly increase a lot when detM~k≈0 and |υ~k|≈0. This kind of phenomena, which seriously reduces the accuracy, occurs twice in a period of rotation. In order to avoid this periodic singularity, a modified REOLAE is proposed: if detM~k≈0 and |υ~k|≈0, terminate the current recursive process, and create a new recursive process discarding all past measurements. The modified approach could significantly reduce the maximum attitude error. Figure 3(b) shows that the optimal relative weighting ρk* of modified REOLAE periodically varies with time going. Figure 3.
Attitude accuracy plots (rotating).

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p: A new SP attitude estimator called OLAE is proposed via analysis of geometric relationships of rotation, and a recursive algorithm called REOLAE is developed in this article. OLAE is based on the linear relationships, obtained using dot and cross products to eliminate the unknown parameters, between measurements and Gibbs vector. Singularity avoidance is solved through a proper prior rotation. The recursive algorithm is achieved for the purpose of improving attitude accuracy using all past measurements. And the memory fading concept is also introduced into REOLAE for long-term attitude determination missions. An efficient modification is proposed to significantly reduce the sudden increase in attitude error when the body is rotating with respect to the reference coordinate system. Numerical simulations demonstrate the high accuracy of the proposed estimators.

sec.title: Funding
sec.p: This work was partially supported by the National Hi-Tech Research and Development Program (863) of China [grant number 2007AA705411].
